content.text:
# Hokkaido Heritage__disambig_1

is an initiative aimed at the valorization and transmission to the next generation of the tangible and intangible natural, cultural, historical, and industrial heritage of Hokkaidō, Japan. It is advanced by the , an NPO, and endorsed by the prefectural government, amongst other bodies. Seventy-four assets have been identified to date in four sessions, the first twenty-five on 22 October 2001, a further twenty-seven on 22 October 2004, fifteen more on 1 November 2018, and, most recently, an additional six (together with the split of "The Ubagami Daijingū Festival and Esashi Oiwake" into two separate assets) on 13 October 2022. The scheme does not include a formal system for management or preservation but is intended to be a citizen-led movement with the concomitant benefits of promoting tourism, fostering pride and a sense of belonging in local communities, developing human capital and potential, and the revitalization of local economies.

| align="center"|North Breakwater Dome in Wakkanai PortWakkanai-kō kita-bōhatei dōmu || Wakkanai || Built in connection with the former Chihaku ferry that connected Wakkanai with Ōdomari, now Korsakov, in what was then Karafuto Prefecture, South Sakhalin ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-

| align="center"|The Herring Highway in RumoiRumoi no nishin kaidō || Rumoi, Obira, Tomamae || Includes the ,  (pictured),  and Life and Culture ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]

| align="center"|Historical Buildings in MashikeMashike no rekishi-teki tatemono-gun || Mashike || Includes the  (an Important Cultural Property),  (pictured), and the historical buildings and  near Mashike Station ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Asahibashi BridgeAsahi-bashi || Asahikawa || Over the Ishikari River; completed in 1932 to replace the 1892 bridge of wood covered in earth ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Museum of Soils "Mansion of Soils"Tsuchi no Hakubutsukan "Tsuchi no Yakata" || Kamifurano || Tells the story of the agricultural development of the island from the time of the Hokkaidō Development Commission, also of the 1926 eruption of Mount Tokachi ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Uryū MarshUryū-numa shitsugen || Uryū || In Shokanbetsu-Teuri-Yagishiri Quasi-National Park; a Ramsar Site ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Hokkai Principal Irrigation ChannelHokkai kansen-yō suiro || Akabira, Bibai, Iwamizawa, Mikasa, Naie, Nanporo, Sunagawa || The longest exclusively agricultural irrigation channel in the country; runs  from Akabira to Nanporo; constructed in four years from 1924; draws water from the  ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Colliery-related Facilities, and Life and Culture of SorachiSorachi no tankō kanren shisetsu to seikatsu bunka || Ashibetsu, Bibai, Iwamizawa, Utashinai, Yūbari, etc || At the industry's peak in the 1960s there were some 110 mines in Sorachi, with an annual output of ; all had closed by the 1990s; see Ishikari coalfield, Hokutan Horonai coal mine, Yūbari Coal Mine Museum ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_03.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Ishikari RiverIshikari-gawa || Ishikari, etc || The longest on the island and third longest in the country, the river flows from the Daisetsuzan Mountains into the Sea of Japan ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Bricks of EbetsuEbetsu no renga || Ebetsu || Construction in brick was encouraged by the Hokkaidō Development Commission, resulting in buildings such as the Former Hokkaidō Government Office in Sapporo; at one point there were seventeen brickworks in eight areas of the prefecture, but during the Taishō era they converged on Ebetsu, with its fine clays; three brickworks continue in the area today; there are some four hundred brick buildings in the city, including the  and  (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Hokkaido University, the Sapporo Agricultural College Farm No.2Hokkaidō Daigaku Sapporo Nō Gakkō dai-ni nōjō || Sapporo || Founded in 1877 by William S. Clark as a "model" farm ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The European Architecture in the Era of the Hokkaidō Development CommissionKaitakushi jidai no yōfū kenchiku || Sapporo || Includes the Sapporo Clock Tower, Hōheikan (pictured), Seikatei, , , etc ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Factories and Memorial Halls in Naebo, SapporoSapporo Naebo chiku no kōjō kinenkan-gun || Sapporo || Includes the , Sapporo Beer Museum (pictured), , , etc ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Otaru Minato Harbour and BreakwaterOtaru minato to bōhatei || Otaru || The north breakwater was designed by , inspired by the Port of Colombo, and makes use of sloping blocks; the south breakwater was constructed using caissons; cf.  ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Nikka Whisky Yoichi DistilleryNikka Uwisukii Yoichi jōryū-sho || Yoichi || Taketsuru Masataka opened his distillery here in 1934, malt whisky production starting two years later ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Shakotan Peninsula and Cape KamuiShakotan-hantō to Kamui-misaki || Shakotan etc || Remains of the old herring industry, which prospered from the Meiji period to the Shōwa era include a , unloading place, fish ponds, tunnels, and roads ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Natural Spring Water in KyōgokuKyōgoku no fukidashi yūsui || Kyōgoku || One of the largest springs in the country, replenished by snow thaw from Mount Yōtei that filters through minerals underground; selected in 1985 by the Environmental Agency as one of the  ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Skiing and the Niseko MountainsSukii to Niseko renpō || Kutchan, Niseko || Skiing grew in popularity both locally and across the country at large in the 1960s ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Beech Forests at the Northern BoundaryHokugen no buna bayashi || Kuromatsunai || The Oshima Peninsula marks the northern limit of this temperate zone tree; in Nanae there is a beech forest planted by , son of painter Eduard and brother of Hakodate Consul Conrad ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Shōwashinzan International Snowball Fight FestivalShōwa-shinzan Kokusai Yukigassen Taikai || Sōbetsu || Shōwa-shinzan or "new mountain of the Shōwa era" was formed by volcanic lava in the 1940s; this competitive snowballing or yuki-gassen began in 1989 ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Noboribetsu Onsen Jigoku-daniNoboribetsu onsen Jigoku-dani || Noboribetsu || There are fifteen so-called thermal "hells" in the valley, which is surrounded by , with a surface temperature that reaches , the smoking , and  ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Remains of Jōmon Culture on the Coast of Uchiura GulfUchiura-wan engan no Jōmon bunka iseki-gun || Date, Hakodate, etc || Four million artefacts, including "Hollow Dogū", have been found at eighty-nine sites in Hakodate alone; see Ōfune Site|, , Jōmon Archaeological Sites in Hokkaidō, Northern Tōhoku, and other regions; cf. Zoku-Jōmon period ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_04.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Ubagami Daijingū FestivalUbagami Daijingū togyo-sai || Esashi || Herring-related matsuri, some 360 years old ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/esashi_ubagami.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Esashi OiwakeEsashi oiwake || Esashi || folk song ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/esashi_oiwake.html ]
|-
| align="center"|The Former Fort from the 15th Century in KaminokuniKaminokuni no chūsei no tate || Kaminokuni || , built by Takeda Nobuhiro, ancestor of the Matsumae clan; cf. Shinori-date, Yafurai-date, Continued Top 100 Japanese Castles ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Fukuyama (Matsumae) Castle and its Temple DistrictFukuyama (Matsumae)-jō to teramachi || Matsumae || The last castle to be built in Edo period Japan; it served as the base for the Matsumae Domain daimyō and later as a battleground during the Boshin War and Battle of Hakodate; to the north of the castle is a temple district with five temples, , family temple and burial site of the Matsumae clan daimyō, , , , and Ryūun-in; famous for its cherry blossoms ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Goryōkaku and the Relics of the Battle of HakodateGoryōkaku to Hakodate sensō no ikō || Hakodate etc || Includes Goryōkaku, Shiryōkaku, Fukuyama Castle, the waters off Kamome Island where the Japanese frigate Kaiyō Maru sank, Washinoki, where the shogunate forces under Enomoto Takeaki landed, the battlefield of , the , where the new Meiji Government forces made landfall, the , where Hijikata Toshizō was killed, etc ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Mount Hakodate and the Remains of the BatteriesHakodate-yama to hōdai ato || Hakodate || Famous as the location for one of the Three Night Views of Japan; fortified from the mid-Meiji period ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Seibuchiku Area in HakodateHakodate Seibu-chiku no machi-nami || Hakodate || The Port of Hakodate was a treaty port that opened to foreign ships in Ansei 6 (1859); includes the red brick warehouses,  (pictured), , etc; see Important Preservation Districts for Groups of Traditional Buildings ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The TramwaysRomen densha || Hakodate, Sapporo || Hakodate City Tram (pictured) first operated as a horse-drawn railway car in 1897 and was electrified in 1913; the Sapporo Streetcar began operations in 1918 ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Cherry Trees on Nijikken Road in ShizunaiShizunai Nijikken-dōro no sakura namiki || Shinhidaka || With the Hidaka Mountains as backdrop, some three thousand cherry trees, including 90-year old Ezoyama cherries, line a  stretch of the Nijikken Road that runs between Shizunai and Niikappu, to the pastures opened in line with Kuroda Kiyotaka's advice for the rearing of larger horses from the native breeds ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Mōru Hot SpringsMōru onsen || Otofuke || The name is derived from the German Moor, the springs rising through peat; includes  ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Rawan ButterbursRawan-buki || Ashoro || Giant butterburs that grow to a height of  to  along the ; it is said they used to grow to a height of some ; cf. Koropokkuru (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Former National Railroad and Concrete Arch Bridges of the Shihoro Linekyū-Kokutetsu Shihoro-sen konkurīto āchi kyōryō-gun || Kamishihoro || Thirty-four bridges from the early Shōwa era are preserved, including  (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Kiritappu WetlandKiritappu shitsugen || Hamanaka || A Ramsar Site and Wildlife Protection Area; in Akkeshi Prefectural Natural Park; its "peat-forming plant communities" are a Natural Monument ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Lake MashūMashū-ko || Teshikaga || An endorheic crater lake in Akan National Park said to be one of world's clearest lakes ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Konsen Highland WindbreakKonsen daichi no kōshi-jō bōfū-rin || Betsukai, Nakashibetsu, Shibecha, Shibetsu || A grid formed by bands of trees some  wide that run a total of  ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_05.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Notsuke Peninsula and the Utase BoatsNotsuke-hantō to utase-bune || Betsukai, Shibetsu || The biggest sandspit in Japan, extending ; there are remains of Satsumon culture pit dwellings, while in the Edo period there was a checkpoint regulating travel and trade with Kunashir Island ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Wakka/Koshimizu primaeval flower gardenWakka/Koshimizu gensei ka-en || Kitami, Koshimizu || Facing the Sea of Okhotsk and Lake Saroma, the Wakka Primaeval Flower Garden is the longest stretch of undeveloped and uncultivated land on the coastline of Japan and has some three hundred different flowers; see Lake Tōfutsu ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Pierson Memorial HousePiason Kinenkan || Kitami || Built in 1914 as the home for American missionaries George and Ida Pierson by architect Merrell Vories Hitotsuyanagi ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Forest Railroad Steam Locomotive "Amamiya No.21"Shinrin Tetsudō jōki kikansha "Amamiya 21-gō" || Engaru || See Hokkaido Maruseppu Recreation Forest Park Railway ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Ancient Remains along the Okhotsk CoastOhōtsuku engan no kodai iseki-gun || Abashiri, Engaru, Kitami, Shari, etc || Deposits from the Paleolithic, Jōmon and Zoku-Jōmon periods, Okhotsk culture and Ainu; includes the , , and ; see Yūbetsu technique ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Ice Floes and GarinkoRyūhyō to Garinko-gō || Monbetsu || '"Drift Ice in the Sea of Okhotsk" is one of the 100 Soundscapes of Japan; Garinko (pictured) is an icebreaker ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Villages of the Farmer-Soldiers and Military BarracksTondenhei mura to heioku || Akkeshi, Ebetsu, Nemuro, Sapporo, Shibetsu, etc || See Tondenhei ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Hokkaidō Horse CultureHokkaidō no uma bunka || Obihiro, etc || See Ban'ei, Dosanko ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Ainu Place NamesAinu-go chimei || passim || Some 80% of Hokkaidō's Place Names are said to be derived from the Ainu language || ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Ainu PatternsAinu monyō || passim || The three fundamental Ainu designs are the , , and , that are then endlessly reimagined and recombined ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Ainu Oral CultureAinu kōshō bungei || passim || See Yukar, Kutune Shirka, Imekanu, Chiri Yukie (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|The Culture of SalmonSake no bunka || passim || See Japan Heritage "story" #084, Shibetsu Salmon Science Museum ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Hokkaidō Ramen NoodlesHokkaidō no rāmen || Asahikawa, Hakodate, Kushiro, Sapporo, etc || See Regional variations of ramen, Muroran curry ramen ||  ||  || align="center"|I || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Genghis KhanJingisukan || passim || Involves a distinctively-shaped cooking pan (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|II || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/jouhoushi/isane_06.pdf ]
|-
| align="center"|Rishiri Island Fishing Industry Heritage Sites and Life and CultureRishiritō no gyogyō isan-gun to seikatsu bunka || Rishiri, Rishirifuji || The key products of Rishiri Island (pictured) included herring, kombu,  abalone, and sea cucumbers; in the Edo period there was a trading station for traders from Matsumae Domain and the , while the Kitamaebune were involved in particular in the shipping of herring; after the Meiji Restoration, fishermen arrived from Matsumae, Aomori, and Akita; there are remains of a , a port facility for the temporary storage of herring, and a , a working station for fishermen, other inherited assets including shrines and offerings relating to safe voyages and plentiful catches, stone stelai, and lion dances; see Rishiri-Rebun-Sarobetsu National Park ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/rishiri_gyogyouisan.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Asahikawa FurnitureAsahikawa kagu || Asahikawa || Includes the  ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/asahikawa_kagu.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Miura Ayako Literature Museum and Foreign Species Specimen ForestMiura Ayako Kinen Bungakukan to Gaikoku Jushu Mihon-rin || Asahikawa || ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/asahikawa_miuraayako.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Mashike Mountain Trail and Gokibiru Mountain TrailMahike-sandō to Gokibiru-sandō || Ishikari, Mashike || ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/mashikeishikari_sandou.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Hokkaidō Shūchikan PrisonsHokkaidō no shūchikan || Abashiri, Mikasa, Obihiro, Shibecha, Tsukigata || Five penitentiaries built between 1881 and 1893 to house political prisoners from the Satsuma Rebellion, and later for those convicted of serious crimes; see Abashiri Prison Museum (pictured) ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/hokkaido_syuujikan.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Otaru Railway HeritageOtaru no tetsudō isan || Otaru || See Otaru Station, Otaru City General Museum, Former Temiya Line ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/otaru_tetudoisan.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Achievements of Ōtomo Kametarō and Remains of Ōtomo-boriŌtomo Kametarō no jiseki to Ōtomo-bori ikō || Sapporo || ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/sapporo_ootomokametaro.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Pacific Music FestivalPashifikku myūjikku fesutibaru || Sapporo || Founded by Leonard Bernstein in 1990 ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/sapporo_pmf.html ]
|-
| align="center"|Sapporo Soft StoneSapporo nanseki || Sapporo || ||  ||  || align="center"|III || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/sapporo_nanseki.html ]

|-
| align="center"|The Roots of Hokkaidō Rice, Akage-maiHokkaidō kome no rūtsu「akage-mai」 || Kitahiroshima || in 1873,  successfully cultivated the akage-mai variety of cold-climate rice at Shimamatsu || ||  || align="center"|IV || [http://www.hokkaidoisan.org/kitahiroshima_akagemai.html ]
